pros: Upper management very friendly and approachable; open communication direct from the CEO with quarterly town hall meetings at corporate office; good promote from within plan; can easily transfer between departments after 1 year; health benefits offered diverse variety and build a plan option so you control costs and benefits.
cons: While the company has a comparatively generous PTO plan (3 weeks of vacation in year 2), there is no flexibility to negotiate anything more or an option to take additional unpaid time off. Holidays are slight. Corporate office is crowded and those in cube farms can easily feel overlooked as valued employees. Also cubicles have short walls so there is nothing to block out distraction and is difficult to focus on job.

review_title: The best company I've ever worked for
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Melrose Park, IL
pros:
Very respectful and fear treatment! Office atmosphere is so pleasant, no pressure, you feel that they care, I think a lot depends on the department manager, and let me tell you Chanise Spencer is the best of the best! 
Company always comes up with some kind of lunches for the whole division, taco truck, pizza, salads, italian beef, donuts, etc. Always available coffee, soda, water, plates, utensils. Great kitchen area and separate break room. Paid time off and sick days get renewed in January every year, allowing you to plan all vacations in advance.
cons:
Time off around the holidays is a bit complicated, trash can't wait for you to have long weekend during holidays, you may be required to work Saturday before/after the holiday
Insurance offered is United Healthcare - THE WORST one possible, no idea how did they manage to land on the contract with Republic Services...

pros: I do appreciate the further education that I was able to attain; workshops, conferences, etc. I am also thankful for the strong relationships that I made during my 5.5 years at the company. As you read my cons below, do not read them with the thought that I am an unhappy, jaded ex-employee, I did feel this way prior to my departure.
cons: 98% all white boys club. Ego-centric upper management and executives with their natural entitlement for their letters and numbers cars, covered parking and extravagant bonuses that prevent dedicated and extremely loyal worker-bees from any advancement in their career. Don't get me started when the board meeting is hosted at the corporate office; the long UN Summit line of black town cars with one board member per car and their very own chauffeur. Are you looking for a long standing career where you are celebrated for your amazing talents, education and experience? Are you looking for recognition for working long excruciating hours while receiving adequate compensation, work from home options and good benefits? Do not start here. Upper managements quote to the worker-bees: "Let them eat cake."

pros: Exciting, dynamic and have a passion for change. Due to the large number of new hires up to and including the VP level at the Corporate office some exciting ideas are being churned out. Training department is delivering some very exciting materials and aids designed to equip employees with relevant skills.
cons: Top heavy Company - The rate it is hiring specialists in a corporate role at the expense of field resources is driving change faster than the field can adapt to.Company heavy on compliance stifling creativity. Has a "not invented here" mindset. Ideas are not generally welcomed from the field, effectively widening the gap between field and corporate functions.

pros: Incredible culture, caring environment, feedback wanted and employee driven. This company truly wants you to succeed and be a part of the big picture. They invest in their staff, they take the time to build you up and give you all necessary tools to be successful in assisting customers.  If you feel like you are missing a tool, they will help provide it for you. There or tons of opportunities for growth, change, development, and innovation;  Great environment.
cons: Newer company (call center CRC) which means continues change and working through kinks.  The Call Centers and field are not always united and need to remember that we are all on the same team.

review_title: Cannot keep employees, especially good ones
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Benefits. A few good coworkers.
cons: Poor management. Really poor HR. Looses good employees and keeps managements  friends instead of who knows how to do the job. No job advancement possible.

review_title: "STRAPPED DOWN" This company will NOT promote from within, regardless of all the experience you may have!
pros: Weekily paychecks and Benefits..... But thats it.
cons: Where do I start? First of all, if management expects  and receives top performance from us the real workers that drive this company to the heights where it's at...... Then we Expect the same from you Management!. Meaning, we expect RESPECT, RECOGNITION, AND VALUE!!!! Next,  provide us with the proper tools to do OUR JOB (for example: working trucks!!!) How can you expect a driver to go out and pull a route daily without a truck? Seriously, all that training and meetings you guys have, and you cant solve this issue? Because this is an ongoing dillemma. Also promotions are nonexistant, unless ofcourse you play favorites. Again it comes down to poor management and unprofessionalism. Management does as it pleases, and pick and choose who they want to advance and Equal Opportunity is obsolete for the rest of us.  Its simply  just the run around and the "policy card" they pull out when they see it fit and  to cover their butts.....

review_title: A good company that's lost its way.
pros: Great people to work with. Made some great friends. Decent benefits and PTO.
cons: This company has lost its way. It no longer promotes from within. It passes over the folks with 15-25 years in the business to hire outside people with No Experience in the trash business! There are obvious double standards when it comes to management and employees. Management can get away with things that a hourly employee would lose their job for.  Some managemnt shows blatant disrespect for it's employees. The raises are non existent the most I received from and annual review was .35 cents, and my reviews were excellent.

review_title: Does not practice what they preach
pros: Medical insurance and matching 401K are the only positives for this company.
cons:
Management is constantly changing/reorganizing creating low morale which is ignored.  With new management come new policies and procedures creating uncertainty and stress.    Invariably the new policies and procedures implemented by new managers is a rehash of what they did before at a previous job which didn’t work then and doesn’t work now.  
The review system is terrible with the vast majority of employees getting a ‘Meets Expectations’ when about 25% of the employees probably exceed expectations and 25% are most likely performing below expectation.   It is the opinion that performance ratings are manipulated to bypass having to explain to the exceptional employees why they are not going to get a merit rate increase or having to create performance improvement plans for underperforming employees.   HR does nothing to insure the integrity of the review process.
There is a disconnect between the five R’s and the reality of how company management conducts business.  Instead of integrity, honesty and doing the right thing, the focus is on doing as little as possible to get by.

pros: Decent pay benefits and plenty of work.
cons: No work life balance for supervisors or management and they are not concerned with making it better. Lots of useless processes that come down from Area or corporate that create busy work. They load you up with so much busy work and useless B.S. that you can't manage your department. Lots of management meetings of nothing but people rambling on about useless info. They want to write action plans about everything. I've spent time on vacation doing action plans and useless busy work to meet deadlines. Then when you say something about having to work while on vacation, they tell you you should have cancelled your vacation. Really? After work how many 80 hour weeks for how long? Some as much as 90 hours with no days off for weeks at a time. No thanks my life has improved 1000% since leaving that cluster.

pros: The company provides great pay and benefits. Lots of fun events where food/drinks are provided and you can win prizes.
cons:
The managers tend to micromanage and make changes to the organization that are not for the best. Lower level employees are made to do most of the work, which causes them to get burnt out quickly, thus causing high turnover. In the year that I worked there, I think 4 different employees came and went and that was just among my 10 person team. 

There are lots of opportunities for career growth, but only for managers and/or supervisors. I spent several months shadowing a coworker and helping on projects in order to apply for a new position, only to be told it was given to an external applicant instead. 

I was also drug tested 3 different times in the year that I worked there. A bit excessive considering I only worked in IT.

review_title: Was once a great company but currently going down hill. Stay away from Capital Heights MD location!!!
pros: Great industry! Pretty much recesion proof. Car allowance. competive base salary. Lots of room for advancement locally and throughout the country. Good Benefits. 401K etc
cons: Your sales manager pretty much makes or breaks you. They have been hiring a lot of sales managers from out of the industry, who have not idea how the industry works. Same with upper management. As an account manager, you are required to defend aginst  VERY aggresive price increases, which are obvious cases of price galging.

review_title: Choosing a division is like betting on a roulette wheel

pros: great people to work with.... Learned a lot... Great benifits and the best HR ever....
cons: Worked there almost 14 years got fired for using the fax machine after hours.... But i did it probably over a hundred times over the years.... Felt like i was pushed out the door.. I loved my job and  would love to have it back......

review_title: Company is disorganized and very one dimensional
job_title: Sales/Customer Service Representative in Champaign, IL
pros: benefits are decent- dental is awful, commission is very average not above, especially with the amount of unsatisfied customers.  Drivers are usually friendly and easy to work with.
cons: Terrible Management  of operations and sales department and disrespect for employees.  The company has a very poor name around many areas.  The management level have very little experience outside of the company- resulting in extremely poor leadership, lack of versatility and people skills.  The company pricing, especially within Illinois, is not competitive nor does the company have a good name regarding Allied Waste when it comes to the Central Illinois area & into Indiana.  Consistent customer complaints leads to many cancellations and thus decrease any type of commission.  Companies computer systems are also a bit cumbersome to use.

job_title: Customer Service Supervisor in Chandler, AZ
pros: Republic Service has proven to be home for me, I have been with the company almost 8 years as of this December.  In my time with the company I have been able to advance and move around to take jobs that interest me.  I have found that the company really cares about it employees, customers and share holds alike. It is a company that is environmentally very friendly and caring.  If you are looking for a company that you can enjoy coming to each day and continue to grow and meet career goals this is a great place to come work.  It is my home and I have no plans to leave.
cons: The only concern is training for new positions is not always structured as you maybe accustom to with a large company.  The company is working to improve this across the board.

pros: I was so excited to work for this large company and anticipated a lot of growth potential. I like the industry and the direction the company is going. They paid well and had a good benefit program. Management was very warm, it felt like a family environment until I kept having more and more work piled on me
cons: The division I worked in was understaffed/under managed and I was left to do multiple jobs with no extra pay and no possibility of promotion. Once you are hired, you can hope for a 1.5% pay increase annually no matter what you do to try to succeed. I have also never been sick so much in my life. There was more harmful garbage inside the building than outside in the landfill.

review_title: It's a great day at Republic!
pros: We are recognized fully for the job that we do.  There are a lot of bonus programs in place for customer service incentives and other items like meeting or "better than budget" productivity numbers.  Republic has a lot of sites nationwide which gives flexibility when relocating to other states.  Republic also has an weblisting of job openings at each of the sites nationwide so people are promoted or relocated from with in when ever possible.
cons: Working for a large corporation such as this, we can't make decisions based on the need in our market area but more so decisions are based on what Republic Corporate thinks we need.  We have many small competitors in our area and need to be able to competitively run our business.

pros: Good Pay, Good benefits, good pay, good benefits, I liked my co-workers
cons: Have to learn a five page "script" to talk to customers, sales supervisor was condescending, rude and belittling, constantly felt my job was on the line. Contracts with commercial accounts are so one sided is sad.  Have to lie constantly to customers to justify constant price increases.  Just when you renegotiate a new contract company increases fuel, environmental or other myriad of fees.  I just could not, in good conscience continue to work for this company

review_title: Highly dysfunctional company, lacking technology, passion and clear ethics
pros: High level of metrics and measurements to the Nth degree.  Deep industry knowledge among most senior leaders. There are small pockets of excellence / desire for doing things the right way.  Some leaders are trying to change the culture for the better but will face resistance from corporate.
cons: Dated internal technology and support systems; but it doesn't impact the immediate customer experience -- thought make solving problems highly inefficient.  Lack of sophistication / professionalism at nearly every level.  Most everyone ends up at this company not by choice.  Very little diversity in the management ranks = similar thoughts, groupthink, and overall bad ideas.

job_title: Roll Off Driver in Commerce City, CO
pros: In my short time with Republic, I've been impressed with the commitment to efficiency from the other employees, the talk is how to efficiently deliver service to the customer.  I've also been trained by Patrick Lewis who not only is an outstanding person but one heck of an employee, he's trained me the Republic way, the customer is always first.  He's incredibly gracious to the customer and his coworkers and very very skilled at operating the equipment, he's very impressive!, I'm surprised he's not a supervisor.  Also, speaking of supervisors, I've seen Jim and Josh as very good at what they do.
cons: One thing I noticed right away is the time needed to unload and reload the self-contained compactors.  If there was a way to engineer a turntable on the trucks so the compactors could be turned on the truck there could be a substantial savings per truck per trip.

job_title: Customer Service Specialist in Chandler, AZ
pros: the management, the pay, the dress code, the over time, the learning period, how we can advance, my own desk, free fruit, coffee, ice machine, games.
cons: I hope that how it looks right now doesn't become a lie. I hope that it is as amazing as it looks but I really wont know till my first 6 months is over.

pros: the drivers I work with everyday

review_title: Management views employees merely as pawns to be discarded at any time
pros: Health care benefits are decent, not the best but decent.
cons: Way too many structural changes and lay-offs. Management views employees as merely a number and are heartless in the manner they handle restructuring and lay-offs. Some of the Managers and Directors are merely place-holders and have no idea what they are doing, yet in each round of restructuring and lay-offs they are never impacted. Working at Republic = No job security, so if you unfortunately end up working here always have other options laid out. Always keep interviews rolling even when you are employed at Republic because Management has zero loyalty to employees, regardless of your immense individual and collaborative contributions.

review_title: One I would like to forget
pros: Safety is a priority. They are the second largest next to Waste Management
cons: Poor commission and bonus plans. Not designed to promote sales. Upper management is not trained in soft skills and does not know how to motivate employees, Company does not promote within. Very narrow outlook, they are only concerned with the here and now and because of it they find themselves reactive instead of proactive. Very poor process

pros: REPUBLIC IS A GREAT COMPANY. I AM TRASH AND I NOW KNOW EVERYTHING ABOUT TRASH. OUR TRAINER IS AMAZING AND FUNNY AND SMART SHES JUST GREAT 10/10 WOULD RECOMMEND TO TEACH MY FUTURE CHILDREN.

review_title: Best company to make a better you.

Consistent positive culture of safety, learning and development of employees professionally as well as PERSONALLY. Stay a while and you will be better for it,  but once you are in the family it is hard to leave.
cons: You will work long days,  know that coming in.

pros: A company that cares and knows the importance of its employees and their worth .

job_title: Customer Resource Center Supervisor in Chandler, AZ

cons: I continue to seek out cons of the company but have yet to find ANYTHING. This is NOT too good to be true.

job_title: Fleet Maintenance Supervisor in Columbus, OH

Constant training to move all individuals forward and expand areas of knowledge/skill. Great people to work with. Vast amount of oppertunities within the company nationwide!! including Puerto Rico
cons: I was brought into a "REHAB" location, all new management, with that being said I work a lot of hours to get ahead to eventually get the trucks and crew to the company standards, I knew this coming in so I am not complaining rather exspressing my one and only con

review_title: Company has been good to me....pay is different at each branch....based on cost of living I guess.

review_title: A company with priorities that values it's customers, employees and the planet.

Management makes great efforts to hire the most knowledgeable and motivated candidates. It is a huge pro to be surrounded by co-workers that know what they are doing and care about their impact. 
Extensive benefits at a cost that you won't be able to touch at another company. 
The ability to be a part of something bigger/processing and disposal of our planets waste in an environmentally friendly way.
cons: Like any company the size of Republic implementation of programs can be a little slower due to checks and balances. Fair trade off for ethical practices and job security.

job_title: Customer Resource Consultant in Charlotte, NC
pros: The benefits are pretty good and on par with the rest of the Fortune 500. Could be better, but not bad. Good job on those.

They also do not listen to the employees, because they already know everything. Zero team environment exists. Senior managers could honestly care less if you work there or not.  Zero culture zero values. Truly amazing for a publicly traded company.

review_title: Great company to work for, but difficult to move up.

Many employees were laid off as part of the recent acquisition without warning or ability to relocate.  Many of the teammates that survived the lay offs were screwed by the lack of prep work & cross training before the lay off.

review_title: Co-workers were great but after the merge, my position was so-called "no longer needed."
pros: It was close to home and a fun place to work. Co-workers were nice & friendly and we all worked well in our team. You were given the information and tools to complete your job and I thought I was an asset, before the merge anyway.
cons: Obviously, since I'm a former employee, I can see where the loyalty rested in the company. Someone else had mentioned it's not WHAT you know but WHO you know to get ahead.

job_title: Customer Resource Center Supervisor in Chandler, AZ

Very open/transparent leadership and you get a lot of personal interaction with leadership. Everyone lives by the 5 R's and truly takes it to heart.  There is a lot of opportunity within the company and so many doors are open to explore.  It is encouraged to explore those other options as well!  It has been the best career move I have made and the transition has been amazing!
cons: Attrition.  The office could be more fun/lively/colorful. The facility is very nice and well kept, but a little bland.

pros: Average salary and benefits. Made some good contacts. Working outdoors 95% of the time. Learned a lot about the waste industry.

No one is held accountable so it's hard to get help with anything. Hard to feel like you are in a professional work environment when your coworkers are stealing from the company and using drugs on a daily basis. Management doesn't care about safety as they prevented any employees from speaking to OSHA.

review_title: the difference between local  BU and Corporate is amazing

Leadership doesn't promote team work, they are aware of issue and over look the constant problems.  Lack of training at the local level.  Unprofessional behavior is allowed at the local level

pros: Outstanding local employees with incredible work ethic and integrity. Solid compensation and benefit packages. Republic has a defined vision for improvement and change. Very challenging work environment but absolutely rewarding.
cons: Budget goals are closer to unrealistic than challenging. The reality of what a market can support is not given equal weight to what the annual expectations for improvement are. Support is a word thrown around but rarely effectively executed.

job_title: Inside Sales Representative in Bloomington, IN
pros: Some decent people at the local level, though turnover is high.
cons: Job consisted of being yelled at by current customers due to Republic’s insanely high, limitless, and completely arbitrary rate hikes and having to explain their signed contracts less deceptively than the growth reps did. It turns out people don’t like being trapped in perpetually renewing contracts without being told.

review_title: Great Company, Great People, Great Opportunities
job_title: Area Sales Director in Richmond, CA
pros: Stability, people, pay, education and advancement.
cons: No cons... the company takes care of it's people and the best people appreciate being recognized and compensated for their efforts.

job_title: Outside Sales Representative in Houston, TX

cons: Management is horrible.  Never seen operations so inefficient and unwilling to take care of the customer.  Everyone is always frustrated that they can't get the help they need.  Management always making things too complicated and throwing people under the bus for anything under the sun.  Unrealistic expectations, no desire to take care of the customers.  It takes them 2 weeks to make a five minute decision.

job_title: Customer Resource Consultant in Fishers, IN

Great culture encouraged by an equally great management and HR team. Enormous growth opportunity for the focused. I actually got promoted after about 2 months. Weekly free lunch, free fruits and coffee available everyday. World class interior design and ergonomic work stations. Management comes up with regular spiffs and bonuses for motivation. The best of colleagues with wonderful team spirit. There cannot be a better place to work.
cons: Yet to find any cons

job_title: Swing Driver in Fort Wayne, IN
pros: Republic is a great place to work because they are not only concerned about making money but also your welfare and safety. They invest a lot of time and money into each employee to be sure each one is safe and comfortable in they line of duty. I am a former owner of a  waste company that was recently purchased by Republic Services here in Fort Wayne,  IN. Its great to work for such an outstanding company.
cons: While there may be some "cons" the "pros" well out weight them so nothing to worry about.

pros: Great company to work for. I love the vision and the road map this company has laid out. I've been apart of this company i seen growth great training. I would highly recommend this company to anyone who would like to grow with a company, so many moving parts and lots of opportunity.
cons: As an supervisor the compensation could be better, we are on call 24-7 through emails to phone calls from employees, customers vendors ect.calling us on our time off.

review_title: Republic Services is a decent place to work.
job_title: Account Manager in Mount Laurel, NJ

cons: Intra-office politics leave a lot to be desired, as one department feels pitted against another due to a difference in managing styles. Also, the benefits are not that great, they are expensive for both prescriptions and doctors' visits.

review_title: Loved my job but upper management needs better HR skills
job_title: Residential Driver in De Soto, IL
pros: Good pay co-workers were great people and immediate supervisor was a good man. Over all, good place to work. Thought I would retire from this job.

pros: There is opportunity for advancement, benefits are decent.
cons: Trucks, trucks, trucks.  We need trucks that are up to do the job every day we spend more time chasing our tails then we do picking up customers some days.

job_title: Operations Manager in Kansas City, KS

cons: With every culture shift comes resistance. The message is sometimes lost in translation. Don’t expect to succeed without being resourceful and relentless. Some days feel overwhelming but a mentor is always there to guide and encourage.

review_title: Something smells at the call center

cons: Getting yelled at over garbage and not being able to take a few minutes to decompress is pretty stressful. You have to be logged on to the phone system at all times and only certain disposition codes are counted towards your productivity. You cannot put people on hold if you need to ask a question. You get approx 8 minutes of total restroom time aside from your scheduled breaks. Managers only care about your numbers, this is truly a call center.

pros: Weekly pay, decent benefits and Paid Time Off for salaried employees, and that is it. There are no other Pros except that the drivers that you’ll get to know are some of the best people out there.
cons: TERRIBLE pay, EVEN MORE TERRIBLE management, other account managers & sales reps stealing sales & commissions, from your accounts & managers allowing their favorites to do so, no training in actual job expectations - just “RLTP’s” (online training) for corporate expectations - not actual job, high turn over rate, treat employees disrespectfully, managers will lie and make up false complaints to get rid of people or to cover for their own mistakes, managers and GMs allowing employees to make racist and sexual jokes in the work place. Managers talk inappropriately of current & former employees. HR covers for them. Even when employees resign they walk the employee out like they’re a criminal, and send out emails to remaining staff making it sound like they were fired.

review_title: Run... Run far far away from Fall River Massachusetts (MA)
pros: Cheap insurance.  Safety.  Processes are by the book.  But... You will finally find out what you want to do with your life when you leave this place.
cons: Backstabbing, undermining, a world of chaos but that's what they want locally to keep the meat-grinder going.  You can never hold anyone accountable if the leadership keeps changing. pros: Great company, benefits are top notch. Republic Services is a company that treats their employees as family. They invest in their talent. Extremely pro Veteran.

pros: The pay is reasonably competitive and the benefits are OK.  Very little micromanagement but this can work against the employee as well.  There is almost always free food available and lots of little benefits like a small Christmas bonus.

Nepotism runs rampant and there is WAY too much "I'll tell my daddy about this" going on.  Stress is extraordinarily high, due mainly to extremely large work loads because of under-staffing.  Most employees must work 10-20 hours of overtime every week just to get their work done.  This was a constant complaint in the department but the only response ever received was that hiring more people was "not in the budget".  There is absolutely no legitimate training provided and you will learn by watching other people and then by making mistakes, which you will then get in trouble for.  Dealing with the satellite divisions is terrible, as half the time the correct contact will not even respond to you and you will have to escalate the situations to the highest level of management at these places to get anything done, which is a ridiculous waste of time.  Many of the job-related problems could be easily fixed with updates to software and procedures, but these suggestions are nearly unanimously shot down by the IT or executive departments as too expensive or not worthy of approval (even if they are approved, they take 6-12 months to implement after which more problems have already taken their place).

The management is horrendous at all levels, even the executive.  Every single one of them will push off their work onto their employees on a daily basis and act as though this is part of your job if anyone complained.  Meanwhile, the only work they do is go to meetings all day long, where they do nothing but sit on their phones and laptops and do not even pay any attention to what is going on.  They are making upwards of $100,000 a year but can barely even utilize Microsoft Outlook.  They have absolutely zero technical skills and could not do the job their employees do if they had a gun to their head.  Whenever a mistake is made on a case (even if the mistake is not yours), you WILL be blamed for it by management and have to take the blame when speaking to the customer, because "the customer does not care about excuses".  They whine constantly about the most basic parts of their jobs but make a giant deal out of any complaints that may come their way from their employees.  When you have finally achieved a point where you could apply to transfer out of the department, they will make up things to write you up for so you can't leave.  Dealing with them was truly the worst part of this job.

Really, it might seem like a good opportunity at first light, but make sure you talk to the other employees honestly before committing to this company.  They WILL be honest with you about how backwards the company is, whereas the management will LIE to you to make themselves look better and to get you in the door.  DO NOT BE FOOLED.

If the customer balks and tries to "quit"; we are instructed to hold them to the letter of the contract or if no valid contract exists, implement a "save at all costs" strategy; a slash and burn tactic to ruin the profitability of the competitor.   There is a wannabe tough guy attitude at the very top of the company.  We see in the annual recording of the GM conference his idle threatening statements like "do it our way or go someplace else" management style.  Many, many people choose the latter as it turns out.  From a management perspective, HR is a joke.  The tough guy attitude continues down through all levels of HR, who are entitled to be judge, jury and executioner on the many HR issues that occur in this  bullying environment.

review_title: Started out great, then has gone steadily downhill
pros: The company as a whole is great.  They have very good benefits, with a good pay range for (most) employees, standard vacation policy that increases with seniority, basically good working environment overall.  For the most part, when you call someone for assistance, they provide it.  The upper management levels have a vision that is clear and easy to understand, and can make you a believer.  Depending on where you work - literally - the location is either really, really, nice or really, really ugly.  Even though it is the garbage company, some locations are so clean and well-cared for that you can't tell that's where you are.
cons:
Upper management visions and goals get disconnected downstream and by the time they get to the level where they are expected to be enthusiastically carried out, they get lost, and sometimes not implemented at all.  Again, however, this does matter where your location is and the relationship the manager has with upper levels.
There is very little respect for the "worker bees" and the level/amount of workload and stress they are expected to carry.  It is not uncommon for an office employee to work 50+ hour weeks, including Saturdays, in order to get the job done.  There is no cross-training.
Trash truck drivers are expected, no matter the weather or conditions of the truck, to stay within the DOT guidelines at all times.  They are labeled as incompetent or lazy if they cannot do their route within the timeline the company has determined.  
Favoritism abounds.  If they like you, you have it made.  If they don't, watch your back.  If you complain about anything, it goes nowhere.  If you compliment, it goes nowhere.  The chain of command is expressly followed and if you go around it for whatever reason, be prepared.
Not all locations are recognized for their awards or commendations.  Again, depends on where it is located.  Some GM's do not want any lights shown on them, no matter how good it makes them look, because then they have to "entertain" visitors, and they don't want to.

cons:
- Most of the important information in the company is tribal knowledge, shared orally.
- The *vast majority* of leaders in the org, starting as low as the Sr. Manager level, are white, cisgendered, heterosexual men who have wives who stay at home, so there is a lot of tribalism among this group of leaders. 
- It is very difficult for people outside this majority demographic to truly have positive influence in the organization unless they conform to the norms of the majority group. Conformity is the antidote to innovation.
- Leadership is unwilling to make meaningful investments necessary for the future of the organization (e.g. technology) in exchange for keep their costs down and the stock prices high.
- Old school, "must be present to win" mentality when it comes to work. 
- Lots of complicity among all levels of the organization. No one is rewarded for thinking differently and is generally penalized for doing so.

job_title: Rear Load Driver in Baltimore, MD
pros: Good company to work for. The environment is fairly positive, management is encouraging and willing to listen to any questions or concerns. I have worked for another large trash company, and I cam say that the Republic is definitely more relaxed and friendly. They are willing to reward those who work hard. I have been given opportunities every week since I started to make more money, whether it be working Saturday, or doing extra work after my route is done. There's also opportunities for one man routes which pay more. Safety is definitely a priority at this company, they don't just talk it. They aren't perfect, but they do try to be safe most of the time. Routes are pretty reasonable. Start times aren't too early, days are anywhere between 7-9 hours. Definitely room to move up in the company if you prove yourself worthy. The company only hires CDL drivers, no helpers. You get paid for down time, so if you're broke down or waiting on a truck or your partner or whatever, they compensate you for that. Good benefits.
cons: Trucks have definitely seen better days. The truck I drive has been in the shop 3 times in the last 2 weeks for the same problem, and each time it comes back "repaired" only to start acting up again within a couple of days. If you've worked at a company this large then you know that this is pretty normal, at least in my experience it has been. The company uses a temp agency for helpers, so if you're doing a rearload route, there is the possibility you'll have to work with a temp. This is completely ridiculous to me because Republic claims to be dedicated to safety and quality service, then they bring in guys who are making 8$ an hour and who usually don't care about the job they are doing. It's also dumb because we're paid by the day, and they're paid by the hour. Being a garbage man does not require a great deal of intelligence, but to bring in people who have little to no training in the field, and no reason to care about the job they're doing, is completely asinine. It saves the company money, and that's why they do it. But it puts us in consistently dangerous situations because we're working with untrained and largely unmotivated individuals. They claim it's just a temporary solution until they hire more drivers, but from what I've been told it's been going on for several years. Company pays by the day, which I don't mind but some might not like that. If you work hard you come out on top in my experience with day rate.

So what this forces a lot of the drivers to do is operate the truck from the left hand side. Anyone who has operated one of these trucks knows it is safer to pick up carts while driving from the right hand side. You can see cars backing out of driveways easier, watch for kids coming out to see the garbage truck and watch for kids and adults that walk under the automated arm while it is up in the air which happens more than you think and mostly by adults. I believe in the Republic Way and what we are striving to achieve through differentiation. Does this mean that I think Republic is perfect? No. However, I know that the teams I work for value me and what I bring to the table.  I have witnessed a consistent change in the company in the three years I have been employed and I am proud to say I work for Republic.  I get excited when I am explaining projects I get to work on and the ability to work with many different people. Congruency between BUs -  This may seem small but congruency can do a great deal to further our culture and ensure that the Republic Way is demonstrated throughout the entire company at all levels.  As an HR manager, it would be great if I could go into any facility and know that I will see consistency from the appearance of our buildings, our branding, down to our postings and office organization. 
The restructure last year - the restructuring was communicated as thought it intended to remove roadblocks. However, it just placed those roadblocks at the area level.  We have so many people at the area level giving different direction and priorities that I can see my teams feeling exhausted, overwhelmed and sometimes a little beat up.

review_title: Great Industry.  Great Company.  Going in the Right Direction.

There is talk of moving to a more streamlined environment with tablets, new systems and vendors, but this is slow to happen.  Some of the new additions to senior roles in corporate are from outside the industry or have been away from day to day operations so long that they are unaware or unable to understand how their decisions may not jive with the realities of "on the ground" work.  There is no tuition reimbursement or tuition repayment program as of today and that would be a great way to attract and retain top players in today's tight talent market.  Also, in the field, Work from Home flexibility is absolutely not an option.  There is a "if I can't see you, I am suspicious" kind of mentality which drives these decisions as well as how out drivers get paid.  Incentive pay is complicated, not helpful, and creates enmity between management and employees.

job_title: Growth Sales Representative/Outside Sales Representative in Carnegie, PA
pros: Weekly pay, freedom to plan your day
cons: Sink or swim environment, arbitrary sales goals/activity metrics, contract-based selling, auto renewing contracts, poor reputation, low morale, high turnover, crappy zip codes, highest prices in the market, hidden fees, unreliable service, lip-service from management. Imagine a prospect in Pittsburgh wants to buy a dumpster, they can call a 412 or 724 number and be directed to a call center out of state that can sell to them on the spot. If that call center can't close the deal, you are sent a stale lead, and prospects that become angry when you try to offer a lower price (I was told by a prospect that it was a very shoddy business practice). Apart from many many former customers, they mistreat their new ones by having no way of ensuring their "99.9% reliability rate" is actually true. Lets not forget, contract based selling isn't a slam bam thank you ma'am transaction. Closing deals takes months, and sometimes years of waiting for a prospect to be in a window of time that they can cancel with their current provider. No one in their right mind wants to spend hundreds if not thousands to leave a contract. Most people are unaware that they don't even have the choice to switch even if they wanted. On top of it all, many competitors will match or beat whatever deal you have. You can't sell to businesses that are associated with an account that already exists, as that goes to the account managers. You can't sell to national accounts, either. I can not tell you how many doors I knocked only to be fed horror stories of how they were mistreated. Try selling someone a dumpster when their neighbor has an overflowing dumpster that hasn't been serviced as it should. I had to respond to customer complaints that would take away from my time selling. Management failed to tell me about how every single rep with my territories failed within a year. If you don't produce, don't plan to have a job. Don't plan on taking a vacation either, because your call/proposal/and visit metrics have to be met regardless if you take a week off or not. The office has bad juju. Its full of ghosts. You need to burn some incense before entering as it is just a black pit of misery. Some very wonderful people work there, but my goodness is it gloom and doom. Thankfully you won't spend much time in the office but when you are prepare to take the blame for lost business and not generating enough revenue. Do you know how many dumpsters you need to sell to achieve your monthly sales goal? More than possible. It is a churn and burn sales job. You will need therapy by the time you're 6 months in because your boss will scream at you like a child, or just not show up to planned ride along days. You'll hear one day that the sun shines out of your butt, and then the next day get put on a PIP. The training consists of memorizing a corny script that you will have to recite, which quite frankly, is laughable. The local competition wipes the floor and is sweeping the market because people don't like to be locked into auto renewing, rate-increasing contracts. The garbage game is TOUGH to win. They'll tell you how bad Waste Management is for locking their customers in auto-renewing contracts, but Republic does the same thing, and pissed Waste Management customers are really the only ones you can go for. You will eat sleep and breathe garbage. The job gets very lonely and you very seldom hear the good things you do, only that you are somehow the reason people don't want to buy an unreliable and over priced garbage service. At the end of the day I was not proud to attach my name to a company that takes advantage of the people that put money in their pockets and food into their bellies. Treat your customers and employees well, and you'll thrive. Punishing customers who have stuck by you by continuously raising their rate is criminal. & once they find out how much more they can be saving with the local competitors, they're never going to return. I get it, you get what you pay for. But you are NOT getting what you pay for with Republic. I've witnessed grown adults cry in the office. Garbage drivers, as lovely as they were to me, they lie constantly about what they've serviced, and honestly, they're probably overworked. However , you can't correct them because they're in a union and will strike. God forbid. Also, you will not have much upward mobility here. Unless you want to become an account manager and get screamed at all day and do wrong by customers by constantly raising their rate and explaining why they need to pay for a service they don't receive :) Also 95% of the sales reps don't meet their goals, so good luck if you want to sip the Kool-Aid!
